Yu
The First Emperor
Yu was a great sage, and he wearied his physical form on behalf of all under heaven like this.

Yu, known as Yu the Great, Great Yu, and occasionally Yu the Engineer, was a prehistoric Chinese monarch who was later deified and achieved legendary and mythical status. He is reputed to have founded the first Chinese Imperial Dynasty, the Xia Dynasty (though the existence of this era is disputed by some historians) and to have tamed the yellow river in order to allow his people to farm more reliably.

It is said that the chinese heartland constantly flooded under King Yao, and that these floods were hindering development and endangering the people. Yao tasked Yu’s father, Gun, with creating a flood control system, but he failed despite nine years of work. Yu continued his father’s work and carefully studied Gun’s efforts with the innovation of dikes, dams, and self-expanding soil.

After collaborating with a master of agriculture, Yu created a system to control the floods through a series of irrigation canals. It is said that during the construction of this project, he ate and slept with the workers, and did not visit his own wife and son. He personally assisted construction for thirteen years, and by the end he had become paralyzed. However, his efforts were successful and Chinese culture flourished as a result.

King Shun (who reigned after Yao) was so impressed by Yu’s engineering and devotion that he passed the throne to Yu. Though Yu initially declined, his efforts had made him so popular with the lords and chiefs that he agreed to become the new emperor. His flood control work made him very familiar with all the Han territories, and he divided his realm into nine provinces. It is written in the Bamboo Annals that Yu ruled for forty-five years and eventually died of illness.

Though the veracity of the legend of Yu is disputed, he was highly regarded by all who came after him. He is one of the few Chinese Emperors ever afforded the title “the Great”, and was regarded as an ideal ruler in confucianism. He also became a water deity in Taoism and some Chinese folk religions. He continues to be revered to this day as one of the best emperors China ever had.

Yu thrives with builders, giving a way to create many of them and giving rewards for using them all up. This allows Yu and you to very quickly become an agriculturally, scientifically, infrastructurally, and culturally advanced civilization.

China’s dynastic cycle provides a good way to get ahead in technology, and Yu’s ability complements this by giving a new way to create builders and a way to boost science and culture when using them. This early game production bonus also allows China’s first cities to become quite advanced, possibly even capable of snatching the first few wonders. Use this to your advantage to give yurself a strong early lead in the game.
Welcome, traveller, I am Yu, the son of Gun. I am the Sovereign of the Chinese people, but I can only strive to be worthy of that great title.
Please, come to a village nearby. I have a construction project underway there that I must attend to, but you are welcome to join me.
I would be more than happy to visit.
Come to my capital, we can tour the constructions and have some tea. It may not be the most luxurious tea, but it is my favorite blend.
Heaven guide you.
Of course you may come! I'll arrange a showing of our finest constructions.
I am afraid I'm busy on project - a dam needs building, but perhaps you can visit when it is finished.
Some builders from my lands wish to learn how to build things, and I myself am curious. Would you permit them to see?
Your people may enter my lands freely.
I cannot in good sense permit this. I apologise.
My people wish to enter your lands, and I hope we have built rapport enough to permit this! I would hate to disappoint them.
I am honored.
I am afraid I cannot.
You have proven to be a good king. I hope you'll prove to be a good friend as well.
Excellent, thank you.
Then... No matter. You are still a great leader, though I wish we could also be friends.
I wish only to surround myself with the finest individuals - and I consider you to be one of them.
You are wise and learned, and a just ruler. There is honor within you, I see it.
You have much to learn, perhaps only experience can teach you. But only if you are willing to listen.
Massing troops along my borders for a surprise attack? This is not honorable behavior. I hope I am right in expecting better from you.

What have I done to deserve such condemnation? Answer me.
You have failed your people, can you not see that?! You have no honor! You are no king!
(You are a bad king)
So we could not be friends? We could not even have peace? I am ashamed, but that does not mean I will not defend myself.
I wish we could coexist, but it appears that is not our destiny. For what it is worth, I am sorry, but now we must do battle.
Agreed, and thank you.
I am honor-bound to do what is right for my people. I will not accept.
It is time that we both lay down our spears and swords, and make peace between our peoples.
You have fought with honor, and so have I. What more could a man ask for? Congratulations on your victory, and thank you for letting me rest. I dare say we both earned it.
Even an enemy deserves his last rights. I hope that you will find peace in the next life. Heaven bless you, and fare well.
